Dear Amanda Waidelich:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation On 8/9/24, a staff member gave a youth the wrong medication. All
appropriate medical parties were contacted following this and it
was ordered that youth be observed for adverse reactions.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via video conference on
11/19/24. Complainant reported he had no further information
about the allegations besides what was in the complaint.
Complainant reported he felt the facility handled the situation
immediately and addressed it appropriately.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 11/20/24.
Staff 1 reported on the date of the incident, there was a lot going
on. Staff 1 reported there was a youth having an escalated
episode in the milieu, so the rest of the youth were in the game
room with staff to give the escalated youth space. Staff 1 reported
she passed medications for Youth A and Youth B at the same
time in the game room. Staff 1 reported while she was trying to
give Youth A his medications, Youth B came up behind her and
was nitpicking with her. Staff 1 reported Youth B’s action
distracted her, and she accidently gave Youth A the wrong cup of
medications. Staff 1 reported she realized the mistake
immediately because Youth A and Youth B’s names were written
on their individual medication cups. Staff 1 reported she
immediately completed an incident report, as well as notifications
to all appropriate parties. Staff 1 reported Youth A was checked
out by medical staff at the facility, and medical staff reported
Youth A just needed to be observed for any adverse reactions to
the medications. Staff 1 reported she has never had a medication
error before. Staff 1 reported she has learned from the situation
and no longer attempts to pass medication for more than one
youth at a time.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 11/26/24. Staff 2 reported
he worked on 8/9/24 and remembers hearing something later
about a medication mix-up. However, Staff 2 reported he wasn’t
involved in the situation, and wasn’t aware during the shift
anything occurred.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Incident report dated 8/9/24 authored by Staff 1 states she
was passing medications when Youth A was mistakenly
given Youth B’s medications. Staff 1 contacted nursing,
clinical, and Youth A’s Foster Care Worker. Nursing told
Staff 1 to monitor for any adverse reactions to the
medication. States medication provided was “Amphet/Dextr
Tab 10 mg”.
2

• Youth A’s medication log summary verifies the medication
provided to him on 8/9/24 “Amphet/Dextr Tab 10 mg” was
not on his medication list.
• Health Services Policy and Procedure states all
medication-trained staff will administer medication in
accordance with Medication Administration and Control
Policy.
• Medication Administration and Control Policy states staff
are to prepare one youth’s medications at a time. Prepare
medications carefully, using the six rights of medication
(right medication, in the right dose, at the right time, by the
right route, for the right person, and the right
documentation). Staff are to positively identify the youth
served using two identifiers (name, photo, date of birth,
confirming with familiar staff) before medication is
administered.
• Medication and Adverse Reactions Policy states a
medication error is defined as any error that occurs in the
transcription, administration, and/or documentation of
medications. If an error is made, employees should
acknowledge any error, and assess the consumer by taking
vitals, completing a visual assessment, and making
required notifications. Nursing will assess and provide
further instruction, as needed. Incident report is required to
be completed.
• Staff 1 has two disciplinary records in her employee file,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 1 was trained in
medication administration and monitoring on 12/17/22 and
1/17/24.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as per interviews
conducted and documentation reviewed, Staff 1 did not follow the
facility’s Medication Administration and Control Policy which says
staff are to prepare one youth’s medication at a time. As a result,
Youth A was provided the wrong medication on 8/9/24.
Conclusion Violation Established
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
